posts.title: Welcome to the MuzHack Blog!
posts.markdown: We're very happy to wish you welcome to the all new MuzHack blog! This will be the primary source for sharing news about the [MuzHack platform](https://muzhack.com). Stay tuned for interesting content, such as upcoming workshops.
posts.html: We're very happy to wish you welcome to the all new MuzHack blog! This will be the primary source for sharing news about the MuzHack platform. Stay tuned for interesting content, such as upcoming workshops.

posts.title: Befaco Spring Reverb Eurorack Module
posts.markdown:
![spring reverb](/content/images/2016/06/Reverb_p_foto.png)

I recently finished building my very own [Befaco Spring Reverb](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/befaco-spring-reverb) module for [Eurorack synthesizer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_synthesizer), by assembling a DIY kit from the awesome people at [Befaco](befaco.org). It was a very challenging, but all the more fun project. I can only hope it works as I haven't tested it yet... It's no doubt going to sound great! :)

Read the [instructions](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/befaco-spring-reverb#instructions) over at MuzHack to find out how to build it for yourself!
posts.html:
I recently finished building my very own Befaco Spring Reverb module for Eurorack synthesizer, by assembling a DIY kit from the awesome people at Befaco. It was a very challenging, but all the more fun project. I can only hope it works as I haven't tested it yet... It's no doubt going to sound great! :)

Read the instructions over at MuzHack to find out how to build it for yourself!

posts.title: Electric Mbira
posts.markdown:
![Electric mbira](https://storage.googleapis.com/muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/electric-mbira/pictures/1-electric-mbira.jpg)

With the kind permission of Tom Whitwell (AKA [Music Thing Modular](http://musicthing.co.uk/modular/)), I added his amazing [electric mbira instrument](https://medium.com/music-thing-modular-notes/how-to-build-an-electric-mbira-from-titanium-bicycle-spokes-and-radio-controlled-boat-parts-93d59a0ff584#.sciwwa175) to [MuzHack](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/electric-mbira). Hopefully this [cool recipe](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/electric-mbira#instructions) will be supplemented with a workshop in the not too far future!
posts.html: With the kind permission of Tom Whitwell (AKA Music Thing Modular), I added his amazing electric mbira instrument to MuzHack. Hopefully this cool recipe will be supplemented with a workshop in the not too far future!

posts.title: Parasite - Custom Firmware for Mutable Instruments Clouds
posts.markdown:
![Clouds](http://mutable-instruments.net/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/clouds_slide_6.jpg)

[Clouds](http://mutable-instruments.net/modules/clouds/) is a [Eurorack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doepfer_A-100) synthesizer module produced by the prolific French manufacturer [Mutable Instruments](http://mutable-instruments.net/), whose innovative and stylish modules have become very popular since the company's inception in 2011.

While Mutable have a great variety of both digital and analog Eurorack modules under their belt, Clouds is a so called [granular synthesizer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granular_synthesis), meaning it is really an advanced type of sampler that chops the signal into many small pieces ("grains") which the player is afforded great control over through parameters such as grain size, density and pitch. These sample grains may be played back in an overlapping manner and often at differing speeds/sample positions/pitches/spatial positions so that together they form so called grain clouds, which ought to be what the name of this module alludes to.

Clouds is a bit different from conventional granular synthesizers, in that it focuses on real-time processing of incoming audio, rather than simply playing back samples (although it can do this too, by "freezing" its input). The really cool thing about this module is the ability to manipulate its synthesis parameters (e.g. grain size/density/pitch) through control voltage sent by other modules, which really opens up for a lot of interesting possibilities in sound shaping.

## Alternative Firmware
Now, to the real topic of this post. Clouds, like Mutable's other offerings, is open, both when it comes to hardware and software. The community has taken advantage of this by producing alternative firmwares for it; I have installed the so-called [Parasite firmware](https://mqtthiqs.github.io/parasites/clouds.html) for it myself, and am very happy with the improvements it brings over the standard firmware!

Parasite offers the following modifications relative to the original firmware, according to its author Matthias Puech:

* The Oliverb, a new, full-featured creative reverb mode based on the reverb of the original firmware (itself based on a description of the Lexicon 480L), and inspired in design by the Erbe Verb, with CV control over all parameters. It is largely modeless, probably unrealistic and goes far beyond your traditional reverb.
* Resonestor, a polyphonic resonator processor with built-in support for your beloved Karplus-Strong synthesis. Plucked or fed with your favorite sound, it spits out strange guitar sounds, lush chords, evolving drones, and more.
* More envelopes for your grains: the Texture knob allows to select ramp down or ramp up-shaped grains. Square-shaped grains have steeper edges for extra glitch.
* Availability of much smaller grains compared to the official firmware.
* Enhanced looping delay and time stretcher modes: tempo syncing with clock multiplier/divisor, support for stereo delay (ping-pong delay) and (crude) open feedback loop, much improved sound quality, faster delay time change.

### Installing the Parasite Firmware
The Parasite firmware is installed [in the same way as the standard firmware](http://mutable-instruments.net/modules/clouds/manual); by playing back a .wav file into the module's input. The author warns that there have been cases of the module getting bricked as a result of replacing the firmware, but apparently they have been few and far between (approximately 1%). With an FTDI/JTAG adapter and a computer bricked modules should be  recoverable in any case.

For full instructions on how to install the Parasite firmware, see [the official page](https://mqtthiqs.github.io/parasites/clouds.html).
posts.html:
Clouds is a Eurorack synthesizer module produced by the prolific French manufacturer Mutable Instruments, whose innovative and stylish modules have become very popular since the company's inception in 2011.

While Mutable have a great variety of both digital and analog Eurorack modules under their belt, Clouds is a so called granular synthesizer, meaning it is really an advanced type of sampler that chops the signal into many small pieces ("grains") which the player is afforded great control over through parameters such as grain size, density and pitch. These sample grains may be played back in an overlapping manner and often at differing speeds/sample positions/pitches/spatial positions so that together they form so called grain clouds, which ought to be what the name of this module alludes to.

Clouds is a bit different from conventional granular synthesizers, in that it focuses on real-time processing of incoming audio, rather than simply playing back samples (although it can do this too, by "freezing" its input). The really cool thing about this module is the ability to manipulate its synthesis parameters (e.g. grain size/density/pitch) through control voltage sent by other modules, which really opens up for a lot of interesting possibilities in sound shaping.

Alternative Firmware

Now, to the real topic of this post. Clouds, like Mutable's other offerings, is open, both when it comes to hardware and software. The community has taken advantage of this by producing alternative firmwares for it; I have installed the so-called Parasite firmware for it myself, and am very happy with the improvements it brings over the standard firmware!

Parasite offers the following modifications relative to the original firmware, according to its author Matthias Puech:

  • The Oliverb, a new, full-featured creative reverb mode based on the reverb of the original firmware (itself based on a description of the Lexicon 480L), and inspired in design by the Erbe Verb, with CV control over all parameters. It is largely modeless, probably unrealistic and goes far beyond your traditional reverb.
  • Resonestor, a polyphonic resonator processor with built-in support for your beloved Karplus-Strong synthesis. Plucked or fed with your favorite sound, it spits out strange guitar sounds, lush chords, evolving drones, and more.
  • More envelopes for your grains: the Texture knob allows to select ramp down or ramp up-shaped grains. Square-shaped grains have steeper edges for extra glitch.
  • Availability of much smaller grains compared to the official firmware.
  • Enhanced looping delay and time stretcher modes: tempo syncing with clock multiplier/divisor, support for stereo delay (ping-pong delay) and (crude) open feedback loop, much improved sound quality, faster delay time change.

Installing the Parasite Firmware

The Parasite firmware is installed in the same way as the standard firmware; by playing back a .wav file into the module's input. The author warns that there have been cases of the module getting bricked as a result of replacing the firmware, but apparently they have been few and far between (approximately 1%). With an FTDI/JTAG adapter and a computer bricked modules should be recoverable in any case.

For full instructions on how to install the Parasite firmware, see the official page.

posts.title: NIME 2016 - Workshop on Sharing Innovations in Electronic Musical Instruments
posts.markdown:
As part of the "Unconference" event on the final day of the New Interfaces for Musical Expression (NIME) 2016 conference, Taku Muzita Lippit AKA DJ Sniff presented a workshop on the sharing of innovations in electronic musical instruments.

The topic of this workshop was mainly the activities of electronic musicians in South East Asia, for example Indonesia. He talked, among other things, about the documentary Bising, which is about the noise music scene in Indonesia. Apparently, the Indonesian noise scene is centered in Yogyakarta, supposedly the cultural capital of Indonesia as a whole.

He described the Indonesian practice of "noise bombing", where a group of musicians bring their often DIY instruments to a venue and perform over primitive PA systems (such as guitar amplifiers).

DIY scene in Yogyakarta is making use of local Fab Lab?

## Asian Meeting Network
Taku organizes a festival called Asian Meeting Network, in Japan, where he invites artists from various parts of Asia, f.ex. Indonesia. Many of these artists have very low presence online, for example in order to avoid attention from authorities (e.g. China, Indonesia), so one often has to connect with them in person.

## Andrew McPherson - Bela
Talking about how to reproduce instruments submitted to NIME throughout the years, i.e. via NIMEhub.

### D-Box
D-Box is a hackable digital musical instrument created by Andrew McPherson and Victor Zappi.

* Stores a collection of short sounds
* Designed for easy circuit bending
* Based on Bela (which was designed specifically for D-Box).
* Feedback loops between software and analog electronics

Andrew has written a manual on how to construct the D-Box

### Bela
* Programmable using C/C++, PD or Faust
* Hard real-time audio/sensor performance
* High sensor bandwidth
* 1 ms latency
posts.html:
As part of the "Unconference" event on the final day of the New Interfaces for Musical Expression (NIME) 2016 conference, Taku Muzita Lippit AKA DJ Sniff presented a workshop on the sharing of innovations in electronic musical instruments.

The topic of this workshop was mainly the activities of electronic musicians in South East Asia, for example Indonesia. He talked, among other things, about the documentary Bising, which is about the noise music scene in Indonesia. Apparently, the Indonesian noise scene is centered in Yogyakarta, supposedly the cultural capital of Indonesia as a whole.

He described the Indonesian practice of "noise bombing", where a group of musicians bring their often DIY instruments to a venue and perform over primitive PA systems (such as guitar amplifiers).

DIY scene in Yogyakarta is making use of local Fab Lab?

Asian Meeting Network

Taku organizes a festival called Asian Meeting Network, in Japan, where he invites artists from various parts of Asia, f.ex. Indonesia. Many of these artists have very low presence online, for example in order to avoid attention from authorities (e.g. China, Indonesia), so one often has to connect with them in person.

Andrew McPherson - Bela

Talking about how to reproduce instruments submitted to NIME throughout the years, i.e. via NIMEhub.

D-Box

D-Box is a hackable digital musical instrument created by Andrew McPherson and Victor Zappi.

  • Stores a collection of short sounds
  • Designed for easy circuit bending
  • Based on Bela (which was designed specifically for D-Box).
  • Feedback loops between software and analog electronics

Andrew has written a manual on how to construct the D-Box

Bela

  • Programmable using C/C++, PD or Faust
  • Hard real-time audio/sensor performance
  • High sensor bandwidth
  • 1 ms latency

posts.title: New Features Added to MuzHack
posts.markdown:
Two major new features have been introduced in MuzHack: Dedicated bills of materials (BOMs) as part of build instructions (for now only available to GitHub based projects) and PDF versions of build instructions.

## Dedicated BOMs

The benefits that dedicated BOMs bring are twofold:

1. Writing BOMs has become drastically simpler for project authors, since they can simply write their BOMs as concise [YAML](http://www.yaml.org/) files, which is much more user friendly than writing the same as Markdown tables. It means that BOMs are also semantically encoded, rather than just baked into the instructions document as regular text. See for example [the one for Befaco Rampage](https://github.com/aknuds1/befaco-rampage/blob/master/muzhack/bom.yaml), which is quite involved.
2. BOMs are presented separately from the instructions themselves, and the containing section can be minimized in case the user wants to see just the instructions themselves.

## Build Instructions as PDF
PDF documents are now auto generated for build instructions. Just click the corresponding link inside the Instructions tab, for example [Befaco Rampage](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/befaco-rampage#instructions), and you'll download a document ready for printing a paper copy to have by your side as you're actually building the thing. Much more practical than having to check the computer...

Unfortunately, the PDF documents have some ways to go when it comes to visual styling. Hopefully this will get better in the future. Remember though that MuzHack is [open source](https://github.com/muzhack/muzhack) after all, and contributions to improve f.ex. the PDF functionality would be more than welcome!
posts.html:
Two major new features have been introduced in MuzHack: Dedicated bills of materials (BOMs) as part of build instructions (for now only available to GitHub based projects) and PDF versions of build instructions.

Dedicated BOMs

The benefits that dedicated BOMs bring are twofold:

  1. Writing BOMs has become drastically simpler for project authors, since they can simply write their BOMs as concise YAML files, which is much more user friendly than writing the same as Markdown tables. It means that BOMs are also semantically encoded, rather than just baked into the instructions document as regular text. See for example the one for Befaco Rampage, which is quite involved.
  2. BOMs are presented separately from the instructions themselves, and the containing section can be minimized in case the user wants to see just the instructions themselves.

Build Instructions as PDF

PDF documents are now auto generated for build instructions. Just click the corresponding link inside the Instructions tab, for example Befaco Rampage, and you'll download a document ready for printing a paper copy to have by your side as you're actually building the thing. Much more practical than having to check the computer...

Unfortunately, the PDF documents have some ways to go when it comes to visual styling. Hopefully this will get better in the future. Remember though that MuzHack is open source after all, and contributions to improve f.ex. the PDF functionality would be more than welcome!

posts.title: Music Thing Radio Music
posts.markdown:
[Music Thing Radio Music](https://muzhack.com/u/aknudsen/musicthing-radiomusic) is a DIY [Eurorack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doepfer_A-100) module design by eminent instrument designer [Tom Whitwell](http://www.musicthing.co.uk/). This is a digital sample player module based on the [Teensy](https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/) microcontroller, that the author has released the full design for (i.e. it's open hardware and software) and does not actually sell himself. Typically, you'll buy a kit from e.g. [Thonk](https://www.thonk.co.uk/shop/radio-music-full-diy-kit/) and solder it yourself. What's special about this module is that digitally simulates the radio-powered experiments by avantgarde composers such as [John Cage](http://johncage.org/) and [Karlheinz Stockhausen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karlheinz_Stockhausen). It does this by providing 16 sample banks, corresponding to directories on the SD card, which each contain up to 75 "radio channels", each corresponding to a sound file. The module provides a "Station" knob, with which you can scan between the "stations" (continuously playing samples) of the currently active bank. ![Radio Music](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TomWhitwell/RadioMusic/master/Collateral/img.png) For added fun and experimentation, there is also an input for automatically tuning the "radio" via voltage ("Tune"), which is typically sent by other parts of the modular synthesizer. This should provide for some unexpected results, as you can f.ex. generate random control signals from something like a [Wogglebug](https://www.modulargrid.net/e/make-noise-wogglebug) module. In addition to the tuning functionality, there's a "Reset" button which will reset the playback position of the sample playing and it also has a control voltage input (named "Reset" too), which lets you reset playback in a controlled or random manner (all depending on what you feed it with). The third main functionality is the "Start" knob, which controls the position where "Reset" will restart sample playback. This function too has a control voltage input to modulate its value automatically, which should have some fun potential.

Music Thing Modular Radio Music Prototype from Tom Whitwell on Vimeo.

## Users of Radio Music Prominent users of Radio Music include: * [Robin Rimbaud (Scanner)](https://twitter.com/robinrimbaud/status/562663428830289921) * [Chris Carter](https://twitter.com/chris_carter_/status/562889299621076993) * [Russell Haswell](https://twitter.com/russellhaswell/status/552213743363690496) * [Richard Devine](https://instagram.com/p/900BnMjQjw/) ## Historical Background ### John Cage From [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credo_in_Us): In July 1942 American experimental music composer, writer and visual artist John Cage wrote the musical composition Credo in Us. It was later revised in October of that year. In the wake of Pearl Harbor, this piece avoided the populist tendencies of fellow American composers at the time, while the piece's title is thought to be a call to collective unity. Styled as "a dramatic playlet for Two Characters", Cage described Credo in Us as "a suite with a satirical character". It was composed to accompany a piece of contemporary dance choreographed by his partner and collaborator Merce Cunningham and choreographer Jean Erdman, who performed the piece at its premiere in Bennington College, Vermont on August 1, 1942. The instrumentation for the original performance included four performers: a pianist; two percussionists playing muted gongs, tin cans, electric buzzer and tom-toms; and a fourth performer operating a radio and a phonograph. For the phonograph, Cage suggests using something "classic" such as Dvořák, Beethoven, Sibelius or Shostakovich; and for the radio, to use any station but avoid news programs in the case of a "national emergency". Jean Erdman recalls that for the first performance a 'tack-piano' was used—one of Cage's prepared pianos, though the pianist is also called upon to play the soundbox of the instrument as a percussionist. ### Karlheinz Stockhausen From [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurzwellen): In 1968, Karlheinz Stockhausen produced the composition Kurzwellen (Short Waves), for six players with shortwave receivers and live electronics. Each performer plays a series of events separated by pauses. An event may be played either with the radio or with an instrument, and it is also possible for a player to accompany an event on an instrument with the radio or vice versa, or to blend both together. Each event has a distinct duration defined by its subdivision into segments with a characteristic rhythm
posts.html:
Music Thing Radio Music is a DIY Eurorack module design by eminent instrument designer Tom Whitwell. This is a digital sample player module based on the Teensy microcontroller, that the author has released the full design for (i.e. it's open hardware and software) and does not actually sell himself. Typically, you'll buy a kit from e.g. Thonk and solder it yourself.

What's special about this module is that digitally simulates the radio-powered experiments by avantgarde composers such as John Cage and Karlheinz Stockhausen. It does this by providing 16 sample banks, corresponding to directories on the SD card, which each contain up to 75 "radio channels", each corresponding to a sound file. The module provides a "Station" knob, with which you can scan between the "stations" (continuously playing samples) of the currently active bank.

For added fun and experimentation, there is also an input for automatically tuning the "radio" via voltage ("Tune"), which is typically sent by other parts of the modular synthesizer. This should provide for some unexpected results, as you can f.ex. generate random control signals from something like a Wogglebug module.

In addition to the tuning functionality, there's a "Reset" button which will reset the playback position of the sample playing and it also has a control voltage input (named "Reset" too), which lets you reset playback in a controlled or random manner (all depending on what you feed it with).

The third main functionality is the "Start" knob, which controls the position where "Reset" will restart sample playback. This function too has a control voltage input to modulate its value automatically, which should have some fun potential.

Music Thing Modular Radio Music Prototype from Tom Whitwell on Vimeo.

Users of Radio Music

Prominent users of Radio Music include:

  • Robin Rimbaud (Scanner)
  • Chris Carter
  • Russell Haswell
  • Richard Devine

Historical Background

John Cage

From Wikipedia: In July 1942 American experimental music composer, writer and visual artist John Cage wrote the musical composition Credo in Us. It was later revised in October of that year. In the wake of Pearl Harbor, this piece avoided the populist tendencies of fellow American composers at the time, while the piece's title is thought to be a call to collective unity.

Styled as "a dramatic playlet for Two Characters", Cage described Credo in Us as "a suite with a satirical character". It was composed to accompany a piece of contemporary dance choreographed by his partner and collaborator Merce Cunningham and choreographer Jean Erdman, who performed the piece at its premiere in Bennington College, Vermont on August 1, 1942.

The instrumentation for the original performance included four performers: a pianist; two percussionists playing muted gongs, tin cans, electric buzzer and tom-toms; and a fourth performer operating a radio and a phonograph. For the phonograph, Cage suggests using something "classic" such as Dvořák, Beethoven, Sibelius or Shostakovich; and for the radio, to use any station but avoid news programs in the case of a "national emergency". Jean Erdman recalls that for the first performance a 'tack-piano' was used—one of Cage's prepared pianos, though the pianist is also called upon to play the soundbox of the instrument as a percussionist.

Karlheinz Stockhausen

From Wikipedia: In 1968, Karlheinz Stockhausen produced the composition Kurzwellen (Short Waves), for six players with shortwave receivers and live electronics. Each performer plays a series of events separated by pauses. An event may be played either with the radio or with an instrument, and it is also possible for a player to accompany an event on an instrument with the radio or vice versa, or to blend both together. Each event has a distinct duration defined by its subdivision into segments with a characteristic rhythm

settings.value: MuzHack is an online music hardware project hub, for makers to freely share their designs.
